newsitem.title: USA: CSCE nearby cocoa ends firmer, but off highs.
newsitem.headline: CSCE nearby cocoa ends firmer, but off highs.

text.p: CSCE nearby cocoa futures ended firmer Wednesday, buoyed by speculative buying, floor sources said.
But persistant trade and manufacturer selling stemmed gains, and kept the December contract from breaching key resistance at $1,445 a tonne.
"Generally, the market wants to levitate higher but every day there has been some selling at the close," one trader said. "It's like there is a battle going on."

Benchmark December cocoa settled up $5 a tonne, to $1,435, after ranging between $1,444 and $1,425. Spot September rose $7, to $1,386, while the back months closed $7 firmer to $1 weaker. Volume reached an estimated 6,219 lots.
Fundamentally, traders said preliminary West African crop forecasts, estimating a smaller and later 1996/97 harvest compared to last season's record yield, continued to underpin the market.
However, they said the market was likely to linger between $1,400 and $1,500 until the next round of estimates emerged in late August.
"The market is in a holding pattern until people can get a good grasp on what the West African crop will be," another trader said. --Patricia Avidan, New York Commodities Desk +1 212 859 1640
